I love when Mitch asked “should we ban plastic?” because I think there’s a lot of misconceptions about that. For one, banning plastic doesn’t get rid of the waste. It’s still there. There’s also the idea that a lot of waste in the ocean comes from less developed countries (less that 1% is from the U.S.). Paper products also take up more space and are more expensive to ship, so why are we just switching to paper instead of trying to fix the actual problem?

Hi Mitch and Greg, I was watching this video again and it gave me great inspiration of my climate change post I put on Facebook every week (I am a member of the Scottish Youth Parliament - MSYP - and our national campaign within SYP is Environmental protection)

I'm old and was born before plastic became ubiquitous, so I am always very conscientious about limiting plastic items.  In fact I was recently outside when  the garbage trucks came and one of the guys wanted to know what we do with the rest of our garbage since we generally only put the bin out every other week.  I told them we eat a whole food, plant based diet and grow a lot of our own food so there is little packaging or other waste to toss. I compost organic matter,  recycle or re-purpose glass,  metal,  boxes, and the occasional plastic bottle, so there is very little actual waste.  Every little bit helps and we all need to be more aware.

There are now a variety of companies with alternatives to plastics.  One start-up has designed a reusable straw that opens for cleaning. You can find reusable mesh bags for produce. Bamboo untensils and plateware. Edible utensils that are safe for wildlife to eat as well as humans. Washable "paper" towels. Cleaning supplies that come in disks to reduce plastic use. If your grocery store has a butcher counter, that eliminates the plastic from meat purchases. The more we turn to these types of products, the cheaper and more available they will become.

I think one of the major issues is the small number of recycling plants. Currently Canada sends a lot of its garbage and recycling overseas to places like the Philippines to be disposed of. High efficiency incinerators and recycling plants here in North America would be a huge step in the right direction to solving this problem. Incinerators would also produce energy and the production of the plants would create more jobs.

Curious. I have the understanding that plastic is a byproduct of fossil fuel extraction (this video can be ready as suggesting plastic is the primary reason for fossil fuel extraction). So I'm wondering, if consumer demand for single use plastic lowers, but demand for fossil fuels does not lower, I assume that the byproducts of fossil fuel extraction will still be produced in the same quantities.

So the byproducts currently being turned into consumer plastic would still be extracted and companies would still need to do something with it. Does that make sense? Or is it that the byproducts that become plastic through heat treatment could be somehow released into the environment safely in the form its in before receiving the treatments that turn it into plastic?

I live nearby to a field where people seem to just dump their trash into. I had always heard that plastics take forever to biodegrade, but I assure you that some plastics that I've seen there (I go there almost every day) were significantly more more biodegraded than I expected. for example a bottle of motor oil looks to me like it'll biodegrade to tiny plastic bits in less than 10 years or so. I think it's the hard plastics that take so long to biodegrade. the soft ones break down perhaps even faster than wood does.

I challenged myself to eat plastic-free for the month of November! I would only purchase food that didn't have plastic as part of its packaging (I allowed myself to consume anything I currently had in the pantry regardless of the packaging though, as a disclaimer.) It was sometimes tricky--and I unwittingly flubbed a couple times--but it was not at all impossible! I was able to get a lot from the bulk section of Whole Foods, which, while being a little more expensive, was about the same price as when I would go to the grocery store and get a bunch of processed food in addition to the stuff I actually needed. I got creative: at one point I used an old bag for rice cakes to fill up with bulk coffee. I've already been low-waste for a while, but this helped further wake up my senses and really look with scrutiny at where the plastic (and waste in general) still was in my life. I've also been vegan for environmental reasons for almost 5 years, and I kind of equate the responses to criticisms of both practices: I've simply become aware of these damaging things in my life, and realizing where it's possible for me to cut them out. I don't see it as a huge sacrifice. I just see plastic and animal products now as something I personally can, in most situations, choose whether or not to purchase and partake in. They're not something I'm depriving myself of; they're something I'm deciding I don't want in my life. I think there are a lot more people capable of having this mindset than they let themselves believe, as we thrive off the complacency, ease, and chosen ignorance of our present society. For anyone terrified of climate change, of plastic in the ocean, I highly encourage you to stop passively letting capitalism happen to you and start actively deciding on what you consume--you can start with something as small as a plastic-free or vegan week or day!

Three years ago I tried the Plastic Free July challenge from Australia, and it was eye opening. They have people sign on to two different levels of the challenge. One is to cut out the Big 4: bags, takeaway cups, straws and bottles. The amped up version is to cut out ALL single use plastic for the month. I figured since I had already pretty much eliminated the Big 4 I would go all in.


This was SO HARD! As you guys noticed, grocery shopping is a nightmare. Not only is it the plastic you can see, but it's the box of crackers or cookies with a plastic sleeve inside it or things wrapped individually inside a package that wasn't obvious from the outside. One thing it did do was push me towards healthier choices. It's much easier to buy fruit and veg without plastic than most other things... except when it isn't. Things like strawberries and grapes are nearly always in plastic, so they're gone now.


At the end of that month, I had a couple dozen items I hadn't managed to avoid, but on the whole I did pretty well. I had thought after the month was over I would be relieved to be able to shop more easily, but I found I couldn't unsee the plastic. There are products I just won't buy anymore. There are things that if I'm going to have them, I will make them from scratch. And there are other things that I worry less about. I spent a lot of time feeling anxious over yogurt containers, but when I really look at it, I use them as poor man's tupperware all the time. My freezer is full of containers with soups and other leftovers stored in sour cream and yogurt containers. So when there is something I want that must be in plastic, if the container it comes in is useful to me, I don't feel too badly about using it. I allow a few other exceptions to my no plastic rule. If something is local and comes in plastic vs something that has been shipped from halfway across the continent, I will take the local thing. Supporting local and decreasing the distance things I consume have to travel is more significant than the wrapping it's in, within reason.


This past summer, I figured I would try Plastic Free July to check in on where I stood, and it was shocking how easy it was this time around. So many of the changes I made the first time around were things I continued to do. There were a few things that had crept back into my life after a couple years, but it was pretty simple to cut them out again. In the end, the hardest thing was deciding to try. I spent a month agonizing over every purchase I made, and the months that followed figuring out what would practically fit into my life, and found once the change was made, it was lasting.


Good job on this project guys. I know it can be tough to be visible doing things like this, but so much of change is awareness. I talked about my plastic project a lot, and it has lead to my friends making changes, not because I told them to, but because they are aware there are choices to be made.

Although I didn't ask my students to wear their plastic, I did a similar project with my second graders last year. The entire school had a week long project about the environment and sustainability, and as part of that we asked all students and staff members to collect all their plastic in bins for a week and at the end of the week my students made a huge mural out of all the plastic to show everyone how much plastic we collectively use in a single week without even realising it.

This experiment is so great! I think it brings out to light the plastic problem in a funny but also educational way. I would add that, yes, consumers have a part of fault in the problem, we must educate ourselves and try to help it, but companies and governments have a big responsibility in this too!! (If not the most). Sometimes we are forced to use plastic and companies can prevent that many of the times.

Nice!  Maybe your next project could have something to do with urban watersheds?  I'm an environmental scientist in an urban environment , and a lot of people don't realize that  they live in a watershed.  In most cities, the storm system (outdoor drain inlets) is separate from the sewer system (indoor drains).  In these areas, litter on the street makes its way directly to creeks, rivers, bays and oceans -- because storm drains were designed to convey only rain and thus are not treated.  Thus, any litter on the street = in our waterways.  REDUCING single use waste is an easy way for anyone to be the solution to water pollution!  Thanks for spreading this message!

Here in Mexico,  a major chain of Butcher Shops Has made a concerted effort to reduce plastic waste by providing customers with free reusable recycled tote bags with the logo of the store and locations and phone numbers.  When your weighed out product arrives at the checkout, it is still in a flimsy bag for cleanliness and safety, but they will grab your purchase with your bag and pop it in and send you out.  My friend there tells me they have reduced by half the amount of extra bags they used by doing this.  As long as Customers continue bringing back the bags.  Also, for my Sister, in LA, the back of her car is filled with the reusable bags, and where ever they go to shop, they bring a few in to use.  And Finally, the most clever thing I have seen lately is a rack of the large bags that is color coded and fits in a collapsible frame that  fits on the edge of almost all Grocery carts.  Looks like a file folder with holders.  As the lady shops she puts items in the separate bins in her shopping cart by group. (Canned goods, Cleaning supplies, meats, fruits and Veggies, Other)  She gets to check out,  they help her lift it out, scan and charge her, then they carefully put it all back into the correct bags.  She told us the only issue she has is if there is no one home when she arrives to help her get all her groceries out of the car in one go!   Little things we can all do!  Thanks and a great video!!!

Looking at the amount of plastics on you, I think you use less than the average consumer.

However, the straw comment got me. I use straws to limit consumption speed and to avoid putting staining beverages on my teeth. I think what I will do is get a reusable washable straw to take with me, much in the same way people once brought their own utensils to a dinner rather than having the host provide them.

I have done things to reduce plastic usage. I prefer to use mason jars for storing goods over tupperware. My wife's lunch box is a wood bento box, and I am using wax covered paper bags more for sandwiches instead of plastic bags (and am considering getting a beeswax linen reusable wrap to replace the paper bags). Small steps, and sometimes I feel like they are insignificant.

Of course, a challenge is my wife working in restaurants at management level. Free food means meals being brought home, which means lots of plastic containers. I know we should get reusable containers, but it is so difficult to constantly be carrying all that extra bulk in addition to all the other things we carry going to work.

I do wonder if autonomous electric vehicles ever become commonplace when mixed with non-fossil fuel energy how that will change the equation's balance of plastics economic value over glass and metal. Then again, I think a lot of that would be dependent on the batteries, as battery manufacturing is very polluting. Am I doing the environment good or a disservice by using a battery powered mower? (My yard is too big for a corded mower, and I don't have the physical ability to use a push mower or scythe... though I do want to buy and try a scythe some day). I wish they made a 2 stage electric snow thrower, and until they do I have to keep my gas guzzling beast for the bad storms. Would a single stage one work better than a shovel, and could I physically handle one that isn't self-propelled? Electric sounds good, but there is no such thing as an environmentally neutral activity - everything any creature does will have some negative environmental impact, it is just a matter of what types of damages are being done and choosing which ones are survivable.

Lets do a comparison shall we?

There's a huge restaurant with 8000 tables. You, your extended family and your friends and their extended family go to that restaurant to eat. You and your massive entourage occupy 300 of the tables. When all of you are done eating all of you take your plates and put them where they belong. However, the rest of the 8000 tables occupants does not. How big of a difference did you make?

China: Over 8 metric tonnes of plastic per year
U.S.A: About 300 kg of plastic per year
